review.title: A Constraint Satisfaction Framework for Executing Perceptions and Actions in Diagrammatic Reasoning
review.abstract: Diagrammatic reasoning (DR) is pervasive in human problem solving as a powerful adjunct to symbolic reasoning based on language-like representations. The research reported in this paper is a contribution to building a general purpose DR system as an extension to a SOAR-like problem solving architecture. The work is in a framework in which DR is modeled as a process where subtasks are solved, as appropriate, either by inference from symbolic representations or by interaction with a diagram, i.e., perceiving specified information from a diagram or modifying/creating objects in a diagram in specified ways according to problem solving needs. The perceptions and actions in most DR systems built so far are hand-coded for the specific application, even when the rest of the system is built using the general architecture. The absence of a general framework for executing perceptions/actions poses as a major hindrance to using them opportunistically -- the essence of open-ended search in problem solving. Our goal is to develop a framework for executing a wide variety of specified perceptions and actions across tasks/domains without human intervention. We observe that the domain/task-specific visual perceptions/actions can be transformed into domain/task-independent spatial problems. We specify a spatial problem as a quantified constraint satisfaction problem in the real domain using an open-ended vocabulary of properties, relations and actions involving three kinds of diagrammatic objects -- points, curves, regions. Solving a spatial problem from this specification requires computing the equivalent simplified quantifier-free expression, the complexity of which is inherently doubly exponential. We represent objects as configuration of simple elements to facilitate decomposition of complex problems into simpler and similar subproblems. We show that, if the symbolic solution to a subproblem can be expressed concisely, quantifiers can be eliminated from spatial problems in low-order polynomial time using similar previously solved subproblems. This requires determining the similarity of two problems, the existence of a mapping between them computable in polynomial time, and designing a memory for storing previously solved problems so as to facilitate search. The efficacy of the idea is shown by time complexity analysis. We demonstrate the proposed approach by executing perceptions and actions involved in DR tasks in two army applications.

metadata.title: A Constraint Satisfaction Framework for Executing Perceptions and Actions in Diagrammatic Reasoning

sections.text: Our goal is to develop a framework for performing a variety of specified perceptions and actions across tasks / domains without human intervention. We observe that domain / task-specific visual perceptions / actions can be transformed into domain / task-independent spatial problems. We define a spatial problem as a quantified satisfaction problem in the real domain using an unlimited vocabulary of properties, relationships and actions that includes three types of diagrammatic objects - points, curves, regions. Solving a spatial problem from this specification requires the calculation of the corresponding simplified quantifier-free expression, the complexity of which is inherently double exponential. We present objects as a configuration of simple elements to facilitate the division of complex problems into simpler and similar sub-problems. We show that if the symbolic solution of a sub-problem can be expressed concisely, quantifier spatial problems are dismantled in the short order of time by the use of similar problems in the two pre-solved problems.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The research presented in this paper contributes to the development of problem-solving agents in artificial intelligence (AI) that use diagrams much like humans do, but most AI do not, as the focus in AI is almost exclusively on linguistic or predicate symbolic representations. Diagramatic thinking (DR) is an emerging field of research in a number of areas to which all rights are reserved, including AI (Glasgow, Narayanan, & Chandrasekaran, 1995; Chandrasekaran, Kurup, & Banerjee, 2005), logic (Barwise & Etchemendy, 1998; Allwein & Barwise, 1999), and psychology (Tversky, 2000; Tricket & Trafton, 2006).

sections.heading: 1.1 Diagrammatic Reasoning as a Problem Solving Activity
sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to take the lead.

sections.heading: 1.3 Perceptions and Actions in Diagrammatic Reasoning
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to defect to the US in order to defect to the US.

sections.heading: 1.4 The Problem
sections.text: How are perceptions and actions solved in a DR system? Typically, the person developing a DR system identifies a priori the problem-solving steps, including a set of perceptions and actions, and encodes efficient algorithms for solving them. If the problem-solving steps need to be changed in the future and, as a result, a new perception arises, the developer must write a different algorithm to get his solution. Therefore, algorithms for each perception / action must be coded by hand. Clearly, this is inconvenient and time-consuming in developing a DR system and does not allow for quick and easy experimentation with different problem-solving strategies for the same problem. These disadvantages are magnified when the goal is to build a universal DR system that allows a very wide variety of perceptions and actions that are not a priori to be determined and algorithms to be developed and stored.

sections.heading: 1.5 Contributions
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this is a problem, which is a problem, which is a problem which must be solved first and foremost in the way in which it is to be solved.

sections.heading: 2. Specification Language
sections.text: In this section we will discuss a high-level language that is finite, expandable, humanly usable and expressive enough to describe a variety of 2D spatial problems relevant to DRs. Problems specified in this language are accepted as input by the PLC and solved without human intervention. The specification language is independent of the PLC, i.e. the problem specification remains unchanged, even if the underlying representation and argumentation strategy of the PLC changes.

sections.heading: 2.3 The Language
sections.text: This is the language in which the problem solver (human or artificial) specifies a spatial problem to solve the problem. (...) The internal representation of objects, properties, relationships and problem-solving strategies is hidden from problem solving. (...) The specification language remains unchanged even if the underlying representation or problem-solving strategy is changed. (...) We use first order predicate logic as the specification language previously described by Banerjee and Chandrasekaran (2007). (...) The language recognizes a series of Boolean operators that use a set of arithmetic operators (+, ·, ·), a set of relational operators (< >) and quantifiers () to express the precedence while the brackets {} are used to express a set of operators.

sections.heading: 3.1 Modeling Language
sections.text: This is the language in which a problem related to the underlying representations of objects / properties / relationships is described in a form that can easily be subject to algebraic manipulation; the position of a point p is represented as a pair (x, y), x, y, as its coordinates.Notation. the x and y coordinates of a point p are respectively referred to as angles by p.x and p.y. The distance between two points, p and q is given by the distance (p, q); the number of vertex points in a curve c is indicated by # (c); the position of a curve c is represented by the sequence of vertex points. Notation. The number of vertex points in a curve c is indicated by # (c); the ith vertex point is indicated by c [i]; the ith point is indicated by c [i].

sections.heading: 3.3 Mapping to a Similar Problem
sections.text: There are two distinct problems, and the solution to the problem has been completely circumvented - the compatible bottlenecks of SPS 1 and 2 exist when the solution of the problem is logically equivalent. (Dershowitz & Jouannaud, 1990; Goldberg & Novikov, 2003) (Thus equivalence cannot be used to determine similarity efficiently. (Let's determine the quantifying free expressions in practice.)

sections.heading: 3.4 Memory Organization
sections.text: The memory in the PLC is organized hierarchically and stores problems in disjointed classes, which are gradually based on the characteristics of a problem in ϑ. After a problem has been divided into sub-problems and their ϑ has been calculated, the PLC checks whether the sub-problems have the same value for ϑ or not, whether their parse trees are isomorphic and there is a mapping between their variables. As the memory hierarchy has a constant height, the insertion of a problem or the search for a potential class of similar problems can be carried out in constant time. Furthermore, the characteristics that classify the problems are discriminatory enough to generate a large number of classes (leaf nodes), with each class containing only a few problems, which reduces the search to a few problems belonging to a class.

sections.heading: 4. Computational Complexity
sections.text: We will now analyze the temporal complexity of the algorithms used in our framework. In our implementation, a problem is a data structure consisting of two fields - ParseTree and Solution. The ParseTree stores the number of problems that occur in the matrix matrix of the matrix, while the solution requires the symbolic solution in a precise form. A ParseTree can be created in the time O (t), in which the number of basic predictors and Boolean operators in the matrix of the matrix requires. Boolean operators occupy the non-leaf notes in the parse tree, while the base predictors occupy the leaf notes. Lexicographically sort the contents of the children of the individual non-leaf notes in the tree. Let the number of Boolean operators and t "i" be the number of children of the Boolean operators.

sections.heading: 5. Applications
sections.text: In this section we will illustrate how the PLC can be used in conjunction with a problem solver, human or artificial (such as, suspended state), to solve spatial problems without human intervention, as for DR. two applications are considered - entity re-identification and ambush analysis - which are considered very important in the military field. The partial problems into which the PLC separates each spatial problem autonomously are pointed out. Problems in the military field include a variety of objects with arbitrary properties and relationships and thus help to illustrate the meaningfulness of the specification language and the efficiency and universality of the PLC. For the implementation we have used Bisoar, based on Kurup and Chandrasekaran (2007), a bimodal version of the hover reference (Laird et al., 1987), where the problem solver uses two types of operators - predicate-symbolic operators, which are applied to predicate-symbolic form and perception-similar operators, a strategy of enriching the state, which represents a problem of the specific state.

sections.heading: 5.1 Entity Re-identification
sections.text: The task is to decide whether the new sighting is the same as any of the entities in their database of previous sightings, or a completely new entity: If it is true, O should have been observed, but since it is not the case in which H and O are hypotheses and observations (Josephson & Josephson, 1996; Chandrasekaran et al., 2004) we will consider a simple version of the problem to illustrate how the task is solved.

sections.heading: 5.2 Ambush Analysis
sections.text: There are two main factors - range of firepower and sight - that determine the area covered by a military unit. Presence of terrain features, such as mountains, limit these factors and allow units to hide from adversaries, and these hidden units not only have the advantage of hiding their resources and intentions from adversaries, but can also attack adversaries who unconsciously catch them while traveling along a path that is within the visual and firepower range of the hidden units. We had already described in Section 1.1 how a problem solver (e.g. an army commander) uses diagrams to chart the safest way to transport his troops from one base camp to another at a given time period. In this section, one curve or region is presented as hiding place and firepower, and parts of the path to another are presented in another.

sections.heading: 6. Discussion
sections.text: The need to access, communicate and manipulate spatial information (similar to engineers and scientists) using high-level language (like ordinary people use it) has been one of the frontiers in AI. It is well known that such skills are offered by first-order predicate logic and that first-order logic is generally unsustainable, except for limited domains. Under the umbrella of qualitative spatial reasoning (QSR), researchers have studied a plethora of spatial computation whose most prominent exponents are mereotopological computations (Clarke, 1981; Bennett, 1997), cardinal direction computation (Frank, 1991, 1992; Skiadopoulos & Koubarakis, 2004), double cross-calculation (Freksa, 1992), 4- and 9-overlap computations.

referenceMentions.context: of fields, including AI (Glasgow, Narayanan, & Chandrasekaran, 1995; Chandrasekaran, Kurup, & Banerjee, 2005), logic (Barwise & Etchemendy, 1998; Allwein & Barwise, 1999), and psychology (Tversky, 2000; Tricket & Trafton, 2006).
The DR architecture shares the idea of problem solving as search in problem state space (Laird, Rosenbloom, & Newell, 1986; Newell, 1990).
Sketchy (Pisan, 1995) is a computer implementation of a model of graph understanding.
Reproduced with permission from Pisan (1994).
Reproduced with permission from Tessler et al. (1995).

The redraw system (Tessler et al., 1995) combines diagrammatic and symbolic reasoning to qualitatively determine the deflected shape of a frame structure under a load, a structural analysis problem in civil engineering.

The archimedes system (Lindsay, 1998) assists a human in demonstrating theorems in Euclidean geometry by modifying/creating diagrams according to his instructions and thereafter perceiving/inferencing from the diagram.

The diamond (Jamnik, 2001), a system for proving mathematical theorems, uses a sequence of actions on diagrams assisted by a human to prove specific ground instances and then generalizes by induction.
The theorem is after Nelson (1993).

Systems, such as, magi (Ferguson, 1994), juxta (Ferguson & Forbus, 1998), and coadd are built using georep for symmetry detection, critiquing diagrams based on their captions, and producing a description of the units, areas, and tasks from a course of action diagram, respectively.
Reproduced with permission from Forbus et al. (2003).

From the DR literature (Pisan, 1995; Tessler et al., 1995; Lindsay, 1998; Jamnik, 2001; Ferguson & Forbus, 2000; Chandrasekaran et al., 2004; Banerjee & Chandrasekaran, 2004), we have identified a vocabulary of properties, relations and actions based on their wide usage for expressing a variety of real-world spatial problems in different domains.

We use first-order predicate logic as the specification language, previously reported by Banerjee and Chandrasekaran (2007).
More recently, Brown and Davenport (2007) have shown that real QE is doubly-exponential even when there is only one free variable and all polynomials in the quantified input are linear.
Another implemented method, QE by virtual substitution (Weispfenning, 1988), is restricted to formulas in which the quantified variables occur at most quadratically.
The problem classifier and combination of QE algorithms have been borrowed from Mathematica (Wolfram, 2003).
Vik (2001) discusses an implementation in Mathematica.

For example, when the space in a diagram is approximated by a finite number of pixels, as shown by Banerjee and Chandrasekaran (2010), the diagrammatic objects lose certain spatial information that might be detrimental to spatial problem solving which can be avoided by knowing the minimum allowable resolution (or maximum length of one side of a square pixel).

For the implementation, we used bisoar, due to Kurup and Chandrasekaran (2007), a bimodal version of soar (Laird et al., 1987), where the problem solver uses two kinds of operators – predicate-symbolic operators that are applied on information in predicate-symbolic form and perception-like operators that are applied on a diagram – to bring about state transitions to reach the goal state from an initial state.
For the implementation, we used bisoar, due to Kurup and Chandrasekaran (2007), a bimodal version of soar (Laird et al.

We will follow a novel capability using failure of expectation: If H were true, O should have been observed, but since it was not, H is likely not the case, where H and O are hypotheses and observations respectively (Josephson & Josephson, 1996; Chandrasekaran et al., 2004).

An alternate definition of the semi-linear motion planning problem can be found in Weispfenning (2001), where a semi-linear path consists of n translations along straight lines each of which is parallel to one of the given k vectors.

Under the umbrella of Qualitative Spatial Reasoning (QSR), researchers have investigated a plethora of spatial calculi, the most prominent of which are mereotopological calculi (Clarke, 1981; Bennett, 1997), cardinal direction calculus (Frank, 1991, 1992; Skiadopoulos & Koubarakis, 2004), double cross calculus (Freksa, 1992), 4and 9-intersection calculi (Egenhofer, 1991; Egenhofer & Franzosa, 1991), flip-flop calculus (Ligozat, 1993), dipole calculus (Moratz, Renz, & Wolter, 2000; Schlieder, 1995; Dylla & Moratz, 2005), and the various region connection calculi (Randell et al.

Under the umbrella of Qualitative Spatial Reasoning (QSR), researchers have investigated a plethora of spatial calculi, the most prominent of which are mereotopological calculi (Clarke, 1981; Bennett, 1997), cardinal direction calculus (Frank, 1991, 1992; Skiadopoulos & Koubarakis, 2004), double cross calculus (Freksa, 1992), 4and 9-intersection calculi (Egenhofer, 1991; Egenhofer & Franzosa, 1991), flip-flop calculus (Ligozat, 1993), dipole calculus (Moratz, Renz, & Wolter, 2000; Schlieder, 1995; Dylla & Moratz, 2005), and the various region connection calculi (Randell et al., 1992; Bennett, Isli, & Cohn, 1997; Gerevini & Nebel, 2002; Cohn, Bennett, Gooday, & Gotts, 1997; Duntsch, Wang, & McCloskey, 1999; Gerevini & Renz, 1998).

For example, the 9-intersection calculus (Egenhofer & Franzosa, 1991) is based on nine spatial relations {r0, r1, r3, r6, r7, r10, r11, r14, r15} between two spatial regions, the double cross calculus (Freksa, 1992) is based on fifteen spatial relations {lf, lp, lc, ll, lb, sf, sp, sc, sl, sb, rf, rp, rc, rl, rb} among three points, etc.

Spatial problem solving has been an area of active research since Sutherland’s sketchpad (1963). The need to access, communicate and manipulate spatial information precisely (much as engineers and scientists do) using a high-level language (much as common people use) has been one of the frontiers in AI.

Not all QCSP-solving systems, such as, redlog (Dolzmann & Sturm, 1999) and qepcad (Brown, 2003), offer such a vocabulary for spatial problem solving which makes it difficult for a user to specify a problem as he has to dig deep into an ocean of equations and inequalities and cannot communicate naturally in terms of high-level predicates.

Not all QCSP-solving systems, such as, redlog (Dolzmann & Sturm, 1999) and qepcad (Brown, 2003), offer such a vocabulary for spatial problem solving which makes it difficult for a user to specify a problem as he has to dig deep into an ocean of equations and inequalities and cannot communicate naturally in terms of high-level predicates.4 We are still far from building systems that can understand communication in natural language. However, research in automatic constraint acquisition from examples is already underway. Vu and O’Sullivan (2008) discuss recent advances in that direction.

metadata.abstractText: Diagrammatic reasoning (DR) is pervasive in human problem solving as a powerful adjunct to symbolic reasoning based on language-like representations. The research reported in this paper is a contribution to building a general purpose DR system as an extension to a soar-like problem solving architecture. The work is in a framework in which DR is modeled as a process where subtasks are solved, as appropriate, either by inference from symbolic representations or by interaction with a diagram, i.e., perceiving specified information from a diagram or modifying/creating objects in a diagram in specified ways according to problem solving needs. The perceptions and actions in most DR systems built so far are hand-coded for the specific application, even when the rest of the system is built using the general architecture. The absence of a general framework for executing perceptions/actions poses as a major hindrance to using them opportunistically – the essence of open-ended search in problem solving. Our goal is to develop a framework for executing a wide variety of specified perceptions and actions across tasks/domains without human intervention. We observe that the domain/task-specific visual perceptions/actions can be transformed into domain/taskindependent spatial problems. We specify a spatial problem as a quantified constraint satisfaction problem in the real domain using an open-ended vocabulary of properties, relations and actions involving three kinds of diagrammatic objects – points, curves, regions. Solving a spatial problem from this specification requires computing the equivalent simplified quantifier-free expression, the complexity of which is inherently doubly exponential. We represent objects as configuration of simple elements to facilitate decomposition of complex problems into simpler and similar subproblems. We show that, if the symbolic solution to a subproblem can be expressed concisely, quantifiers can be eliminated from spatial problems in low-order polynomial time using similar previously solved subproblems. This requires determining the similarity of two problems, the existence of a mapping between them computable in polynomial time, and designing a memory for storing previously solved problems so as to facilitate search. The efficacy of the idea is shown by time complexity analysis. We demonstrate the proposed approach by executing perceptions and actions involved in DR tasks in two army applications.
